slide.title: Drainage of Perirectal Abscess

It’s my honor to have the opportunity to make my presentation here.
Today I would like to talk about perirectal abscess drainage

slide.text: Drainage of Perirectal Abscess Inje University Busan Paik Hospital Department of Gastroenterology Ji Hyun Kim

slide.title: Contents
slide.notes:
My talk today is to illustrate
the definition and etiology of perirectal and pelvic abscess
Methods of treatment
EUS guided drainage
And cases

the definition and etiology of perirectal and pelvic abscess

the definition and etiology of perirectal and pelvic abscess

slide.text: Contents Etiology of perirectal (pelvic) abscess Methods of treatment EUS-guided drainage

slide.title: Perirectal (pelvic) abscess
slide.notes:
Pelvic abscess is defined as abscess in the pelvic peritoneal cavity. It can locate close to presacral, perivesicular and periuterine area.
Especially, abscess located perirectal area is defined as perirectal abscess. Consequently, perirectal abscess is one of the various types of pelvic abscess.
slide.notesNormalized:
pelvic abscess is defined as abscess in the pelvic peritoneal cavity. it can locate close to presacral, perivesicular and periuterine area.
especially, abscess located perirectal area is defined as perirectal abscess. consequently, perirectal abscess is one of the various types of pelvic abscess.
slide.notesHtml:
Pelvic abscess is defined as abscess in the pelvic peritoneal cavity.

It can locate close to presacral, perivesicular and periuterine area.

Especially, abscess located perirectal area is defined as perirectal abscess.

Consequently, perirectal abscess is one of the various types of pelvic abscess.
slide.text: Perirectal (pelvic) abscess Definition Pelvic abscess: Abscess in the pelvic peritoneal cavity Perirectal abscess: Abscess formed nearby rectum Pelvic abscess ⊃ perirectal abscess Definition

slide.title: Perirectal (pelvic) abscess
slide.notes:
Pelvic abscess and perirectal abscess share the same etiologic background.
Including colorectal and gynecologic surgery, and various kinds of medical, gynecologic and urologic disease
slide.notesNormalized:
pelvic abscess and perirectal abscess share the same etiologic background.
including colorectal and gynecologic surgery, and various kinds of medical, gynecologic and urologic disease
slide.notesHtml:
Pelvic abscess and perirectal abscess share the same etiologic background.

Including colorectal and gynecologic surgery, and various kinds of medical, gynecologic and urologic disease
slide.text:
Perirectal (pelvic) abscess Etiology Colorectal surgery Anastomotic leak after low anterior resection (0.5-30%) Gynecologic diseases and surgery Medical diseases Diverticulitis, IBD, ischemic colitis
Etiology A multivariate analysis of factors contributing to leakage of intestinal anastomoses. J Am Coll Surg 1997 Pelvic inflammatory disease and tubo-ovarian abscess. Infect Dis Clin North Am 2008

slide.title: Post op leakage
slide.notes:
Post op leakage is the most common cause for pelvic abscess, with overall occurrence rate of 0.5-30%,
and it is reported that occurrence rate is not different among different technique and site of anastomosis,
slide.notesNormalized:
post op leakage is the most common cause for pelvic abscess, with overall occurrence rate of 0.5-30%,
and it is reported that occurrence rate is not different among different technique and site of anastomosis,
slide.notesHtml:
Post op leakage is the most common cause for pelvic abscess, with overall occurrence rate of 0.5-30%,

and it is reported that occurrence rate is not different among different technique and site of anastomosis,
slide.text: Post op leakage :Anastomotic leak after low anterior resection (0.5-30%)

slide.title: Appendicitis, diverticulitis, IBD
slide.notes: Besides post operative surgery, it can also occur as a results of various medical conditions, such as appendicitis, diverticulits, CD And complication of RT and CT And gynecoloic dis such as PID and TOA
slide.notesNormalized: besides post operative surgery, it can also occur as a results of various medical conditions, such as appendicitis, diverticulits, cd and complication of rt and ct and gynecoloic dis such as pid and toa
slide.notesHtml:
Besides post operative surgery, it can also occur as a results of various medical conditions, such as appendicitis, diverticulits, CD

And complication of RT and CT

And gynecoloic dis such as PID and TOA
slide.text: Appendicitis, diverticulitis, IBD RT and CTX induced PID Tubo-ovarian abscess

slide.title: Perirectal (pelvic) abscess drainage
slide.notes: Methods of pelvic abscess drainage include Surgical drainage Non surgical CT or US guided percutaneous drainage CT and US guided transrectal or transvaginal drainage Lastly, EUS guided transrectal drainage
slide.notesNormalized: methods of pelvic abscess drainage include surgical drainage non surgical ct or us guided percutaneous drainage ct and us guided transrectal or transvaginal drainage lastly, eus guided transrectal drainage
slide.notesHtml:
Methods of pelvic abscess drainage include

Surgical drainage

Non surgical CT or US guided percutaneous drainage

CT and US guided transrectal or transvaginal drainage

Lastly, EUS guided transrectal drainage
slide.text: Perirectal (pelvic) abscess drainage Management Surgery Drainage Percutaneous Fluoroscopy, US, CT guided (transgluteal) Transrectal (US, CT guided) Transvaginal (US guided) EUS-guided transrectal Managements

slide.title: Surgery
slide.notes:
Traditionally, the treatment of pelvic abscess has been either laparatomy with lavage or blind surgical incision and drainage through the rectal or vaginal wall. Under general anethsesia
Although surgical management has an advantage of therapeutic effectiveness, large drains cause discomfrot and interfere with defecation.
slide.notesNormalized:
traditionally, the treatment of pelvic abscess has been either laparatomy with lavage or blind surgical incision and drainage through the rectal or vaginal wall. under general anethsesia
although surgical management has an advantage of therapeutic effectiveness, large drains cause discomfrot and interfere with defecation.
slide.notesHtml:
Traditionally, the treatment of pelvic abscess has been either laparatomy with lavage

or blind surgical incision and drainage through the rectal or vaginal wall. Under general anethsesia

Although surgical management has an advantage of therapeutic effectiveness, large drains cause discomfrot and interfere with defecation.
slide.text:
Surgery Under general anesthesia Drainage by incision or use of needle-catheter technique Laparotomy with lavage Blind surgical incision and drainage through the rectal or vaginal wall (colpotomy) Large drains cause discomfort, interfered with defecation
EUS-guided drainage of a diverticular abscess as an adjunct to surgical therapy. Gastrointest Endosc 2003 Medical and surgical management of the pelvic abscess. Clin Obstet Gynecol 1981 Surgery

slide.title: Percutaneous (transgluteal) : CT guidance
slide.notes:
Minimally invasive CT guided percutaneous drainage procedure was also introduced and established their effectiveness and safety profile, especially lesions located in presacral area.
Although It is complicated with hamorrhage and sciatic n. injury and causessdiscomfort in ambulation and bed rest. And post-procedural pain.
In addition, some proportion of pts remain inaccessible due to lack of an apporiate window
Intervening bowel loops, uterus, urinary bladder and blood vessels obstacle the transabdominal procedures.
slide.notesNormalized:
minimally invasive ct guided percutaneous drainage procedure was also introduced and established their effectiveness and safety profile, especially lesions located in presacral area.
although it is complicated with hamorrhage and sciatic n. injury and causessdiscomfort in ambulation and bed rest. and post-procedural pain.
in addition, some proportion of pts remain inaccessible due to lack of an apporiate window
intervening bowel loops, uterus, urinary bladder and blood vessels obstacle the transabdominal procedures.
slide.notesHtml:
Minimally invasive CT guided percutaneous drainage procedure was also introduced and established their effectiveness and safety profile, especially lesions located in presacral area.

Although It is complicated with hamorrhage and sciatic n. injury and causessdiscomfort in ambulation and bed rest. And post-procedural pain.

In addition, some proportion of pts remain inaccessible due to lack of an apporiate window

Intervening bowel loops, uterus, urinary bladder and blood vessels obstacle the transabdominal procedures.
slide.text:
Percutaneous (transgluteal) : CT guidance Under iv conscious sedation Prone position Post-procedural pain : 19% at catheter site Complications Hemorrhage (Inf. gluteal a.) Sciatic nerve injury Discomfort in ambulation & bed rest Obstacles: : uterus, urinary bladder, bowel loops
Transgluteal approach for percutaneous drainage of deep pelvic abscesses: 154 cases. Radiology. 2003 Percutaneous

slide.title: Transrectal : US or CT guidance
slide.notes:
US and CT guided transrectal approache are safe and useful in lesions located in rectovesical, presacral and rectouterine area
It has advantage of low risk of sciatic n injury and patient discomfort compared to transabdominal approach.
slide.notesNormalized:
us and ct guided transrectal approache are safe and useful in lesions located in rectovesical, presacral and rectouterine area
it has advantage of low risk of sciatic n injury and patient discomfort compared to transabdominal approach.
slide.notesHtml:
US and CT guided transrectal approache are safe and useful in lesions located in rectovesical, presacral and rectouterine area

It has advantage of low risk of sciatic n injury and patient discomfort compared to transabdominal approach.
slide.text:
Transrectal : US or CT guidance Pelvic abscesses: CT-guided transrectal drainage. Radiology 1991
Catheter placement No complications or recurrences Compared with the transgluteal approach: patient comfort risk of injury to the sciatic nerve Transrectal Transrectal sonographically guided drainage of deep pelvic abscesses. AJR Am J Roentgenol 1994

slide.title: Transvaginal : US guidance
slide.notes: US guided transviginal assessment is beneficial method for lesion adjance to the uterine body and fudus, although effectiveness was less than 70%, lower than that ot transrectal approach
slide.notesNormalized: us guided transviginal assessment is beneficial method for lesion adjance to the uterine body and fudus, although effectiveness was less than 70%, lower than that ot transrectal approach
slide.notesHtml:
US guided transviginal assessment is beneficial method for lesion adjance to the uterine body and fudus,

although effectiveness was less than 70%, lower than that ot transrectal approach
slide.text:
Transvaginal : US guidance Vesicouterine space Adjacent to the uterine body and fundus Rectouterine
Lithotomy stirrups Under iv conscious sedation Vaginal wall requires lidocaine infiltration Aspiration only or catheter drainage
Treatment of pelvic abscesses and other fluid collections: efficacy of transvaginal sonographically guided aspiration and drainage. AJR Am J Roentgenol. 1994 Transvaginal

slide.title: EUS guided drainage
slide.notes:
EUS guided drainage is indicated in cases not candidates for US or CT guided drainage because of lack of adequate window for drinage
EUS guided drainage has the advantages of
slide.notesNormalized:
eus guided drainage is indicated in cases not candidates for us or ct guided drainage because of lack of adequate window for drinage
eus guided drainage has the advantages of
slide.notesHtml:
EUS guided drainage is indicated in cases not candidates for US or CT guided drainage because of lack of adequate window for drinage

EUS guided drainage has the advantages of
slide.text:
EUS guided drainage Not candidates for US or CT guided drainage because of lack of adequate window for drainage
EUS advantages enables access to abscess without luminal compression real time drainage under sonographic guidance intervening vasculature can be avoided alternative diagnosis can be established internal stent can be deployed, minimizing patient discomfort EUS guided drainage

slide.title: Prerequisites
slide.text:
Prerequisites Understanding of pelvis anatomy, relationship to the abscess -> CT imaging Laboratory parameters (not coagulopathic or thrombocytopenic) Antibiotics Bowel preparation to minimize contamination, adequate visualization Void urine before the procedure
Endoscopic ultrasound-guided abscess drainage. Gastrointest Endosc Clin N Am. 2012 EUS guided drainage

slide.title: Procedures
slide.text:
Procedures Locate abscess Puncture (19 gauge needle) Aspirate for Gram stain and culture Pass 0.035 inch guidewire and coiling within cavity Dilate fistulous track (graded or needle knife) Pass more guidewire if needed Deploy double pigtail stent(s), and/ or drainage catheter
EUS guided drainage

slide.title: Endoscopic indentation
slide.notes:
Notinfrequently, luminal idnetation was combined on endoscopic examination.
Usuallly it wlll locate within the 5 to 10 츠 from anal verge Externally compressive lesion with mild mucosal edema and erythema was the common finding.

notinfrequently, luminal idnetation was combined on endoscopic examination.

Externally compressive lesion with mild mucosal edema and erythema was the common finding.

slide.title: Deploy double pigtail stent(s), and/ or drainage catheter

slide.text: Deploy double pigtail stent(s), and/ or drainage catheter

slide.title: FU CT and removal stent: 2-4wks after
slide.titleNormalized: fu ct and removal stent: 2-4wks after
slide.text: FU CT and removal stent: 2-4wks after

slide.title: Shyam et al: 25 patients
slide.notes:
Shyam et all repoted results of EUS G TR D In 25 cases of pelvic abscess.
This study included 15 cases of abssecc less than 8cm in maximal diameter, in which case one or two 7Fr stents and 10 cases of abscess greater than 8cm, in which case 10 F drinage cahter was inserted
Outpatent CT was performed at 2wks after,
Technical success and Tx success was 100% and 96%, respectively. No procedural Cx and recurrence was reported although repeat intervetion was needed in 3 cases.
slide.notesNormalized:
shyam et all repoted results of eus g tr d in 25 cases of pelvic abscess.
this study included 15 cases of abssecc less than 8cm in maximal diameter, in which case one or two 7fr stents and 10 cases of abscess greater than 8cm, in which case 10 f drinage cahter was inserted
outpatent ct was performed at 2wks after,
technical success and tx success was 100% and 96%, respectively. no procedural cx and recurrence was reported although repeat intervetion was needed in 3 cases.
slide.notesHtml:
Shyam et all repoted results of EUS G TR D In 25 cases of pelvic abscess.

This study included 15 cases of abssecc less than 8cm in maximal diameter, in which case one or two 7Fr stents and 10 cases of abscess greater than 8cm, in which case 10 F drinage cahter was inserted

Outpatent CT was performed at 2wks after,

Technical success and Tx success was 100% and 96%, respectively.

No procedural Cx and recurrence was reported although repeat intervetion was needed in 3 cases.
slide.text: Shyam et al: 25 patients 15 : Abscess < 8 cm : one or two 7F stents 10 : Abscess > 8 cm : + 10F drainage catheter Mean size : 68.5 x 52.4 mm Drainage catheter flushing (36 hrs) Remove catheter and D/C after CT Outpatient CT at 2 weeks, stent retrieval Technical success : 25 (100%) Treatment success : 24 (96%) Repeat interventions : 3 (12%) No procedural complications, no recurrence Effectiveness of EUS in drainage of pelvic abscesses in 25 consecutive patients (with video). Gastrointest Endosc 2009 EUS guided drainage

slide.title: Retrospective, w/o fluoroscopic guidance
slide.notes:
Another retrospective study included 14 cases of perirectal and pericolic abscess
In this study, aspiration only was performed in 5 cases, and 10 Fr stent insertion was performed in 9 cases
Recurrence was observed in single case in which case only aspiration was performed. On the contrary, no recurrence was observed in cases with stnet inseriton,
slide.notesNormalized:
another retrospective study included 14 cases of perirectal and pericolic abscess
in this study, aspiration only was performed in 5 cases, and 10 fr stent insertion was performed in 9 cases
recurrence was observed in single case in which case only aspiration was performed. on the contrary, no recurrence was observed in cases with stnet inseriton,
slide.notesHtml:
Another retrospective study included 14 cases of perirectal and pericolic abscess

In this study, aspiration only was performed in 5 cases, and 10 Fr stent insertion was performed in 9 cases

Recurrence was observed in single case in which case only aspiration was performed.

On the contrary, no recurrence was observed in cases with stnet inseriton,
slide.text:
Retrospective, w/o fluoroscopic guidance 14 patients : perirectal (10), pericolonic (4) Median size : 73 x 66 mm (42 x 32 ~ 80 x 64) Saline flushing after puncture/dilation (40 mm) 3 : Aspiration only (clear aspirates) 2 : Dilatation and aspiration 9 : Trans-rectal stent (one 10F 10 cm double pigtail) No procedural complication CT (1 week) : resolution stent retrieval One recurrence among aspiration (surgical drainage) No recurrence at f/u EUS (after 3 mon)
Endoscopic ultrasound-guided drainage of pelvic abscess without fluoroscopy guidance. J Gastroenterol Hepatol. 2010 EUS guided drainage

slide.title: 8 patients, w/o fluoroscopic monitoring
slide.notes: More recent study showed that only 1 or two 7F pigtal stents without drainage caheter also effective for EUS guided pelvic abscess. Althoug it is case-reported study, including 7 cases.
slide.notesNormalized: more recent study showed that only 1 or two 7f pigtal stents without drainage caheter also effective for eus guided pelvic abscess. althoug it is case-reported study, including 7 cases.
slide.notesHtml:
More recent study showed that only 1 or two 7F pigtal stents without drainage caheter also effective for EUS guided pelvic abscess.

Althoug it is case-reported study, including 7 cases.
slide.text: 8 patients, w/o fluoroscopic monitoring Perisigmoidal (2), multilocular (4) Median size 73 x 43 mm (45 x 37 ~ 90 x 55) > 80 mm in two one (6) or two (2) 7 F double pigtail stents without drainage catheter Technical success : 8 (100%) No procedural complication CT (1 week) : complete resolution & stents migration (6) Stents retrieval in 4 and 6 week (after CT) No recurrence for 38 months (range 12-52) Endoscopic ultrasound-guided drainage of pelvic abscess: A case series of 8 patients. World J Gastrointest Endosc. 2014 EUS guided drainage

slide.title: EUS guided SEMS insertion
slide.notes: The effectiveness of SEMS insertion for EUS guided pelvic abscess drainage also suggedsted, anlthouth it should be evaluated with further trial.
slide.notesNormalized: the effectiveness of sems insertion for eus guided pelvic abscess drainage also suggedsted, anlthouth it should be evaluated with further trial.
slide.notesHtml: The effectiveness of SEMS insertion for EUS guided pelvic abscess drainage also suggedsted, anlthouth it should be evaluated with further trial.
slide.text: EUS guided SEMS insertion Two patients 10 mm by 40 mm FCSEMS Resolved on CT (2 weeks) -> removal stent No recurrence Transrectal endoscopic ultrasound-guided drainage of pelvic abscess with placement of a fully covered self-expandable metal stent. Endoscopy. 2013 EUS guided drainage

slide.title: Limitations of EUS
slide.notes:
In spite of the feasibility and safety, EUS guided drainage also has several limiatation.
First, it is
Relative contraindications include
slide.notesNormalized:
in spite of the feasibility and safety, eus guided drainage also has several limiatation.
first, it is
relative contraindications include
slide.notesHtml:
In spite of the feasibility and safety, EUS guided drainage also has several limiatation.

First, it is

Relative contraindications include
slide.text: EUS 2008 Working Group document: evaluation of EUS-guided drainage of pelvic-fluid collections (with video). Gastrointest Endosc 2009 Limitations of EUS Not widely available at institutions outside of the academic setting Consider alternative methods Multiloculated Immature walls (without a definitive rim) Located at the level of the dentate line (anal abscess) Lesion beyond the EUS window EUS guided drainage

slide.title: Summary
slide.notes: And these will be a problem for further study.
slide.notesNormalized: and these will be a problem for further study.
slide.notesHtml: And these will be a problem for further study.
slide.text:
Summary EUS guided drainage of prerirectal abscess: Feasible and safe Easily internal stent deployment Convenient to the patients, less painful
Follow-up period, stent size, stent No., need for drainage catheter Not determined
Summary

slide.title: Thank you for attention !
slide.text: Thank you for attention !
